statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.name: rebounds
statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.name: defensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.

statistics.name: offensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the offense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot.

article.headline: Elon University 66, Greensboro 50
article.story: IOWA CITY, Iowa (AP) -- Jeff Horner's scoring average dropped while he helped No. 23 Iowa win its own tournament -- and he couldn't care less. Horner handed out 11 assists to go with his 14 points, and Pierre Pierce and Adam Haluska each scored 17 as No. 23 Iowa beat UNC-Greensboro 83-58 Saturday night to win the Hawkeye Challenge. With 23 points in the two games, Horner's average dropped to from 18.8 to 16.7. But he was outstanding in setting up his teammates and had 18 assists for the weekend. "We won by a lot of points, so that's all that matters," Horner said. "My teammates were finishing great. I just got them the ball." Greg Brunner added 12 points for Iowa (6-1), which won its tournament for the 22nd time in 23 years and improved to 45-1 in the event. The balanced scoring and 50.8 percent shooting enabled Iowa to overcome 21 turnovers -- 13 in the first half. It was the Hawkeyes' fourth straight game shooting better than 50 percent. Coach Steve Alford said that started with Horner, who was 4-for-6 from 3-point range and had three steals. "Jeff has solidified himself as one of those special guards throughout the country," Alford said. "People are starting to recognize that and as we win, I think that attention will just continue to build." Though never in danger, Iowa didn't break the game open until some crisp passing sparked a late 22-5 run that stretched the lead to 29. Kyle Hines led UNC-Greensboro (4-2) with 14 points, and Josh Gross scored 13. The Spartans turned the ball over 22 times and shot just 34 percent. Still, because of Iowa's sloppiness, Greensboro trailed by only six midway through the first half. "The points that we did give up, a lot of those came off our carelessness handling the ball and it gave them easy opportunities," Alford said. "Some of the problems we had defensively were the result of bad offense." Iowa was leading 61-49 when Mike Henderson hit a 3-pointer from the left wing to get the Hawkeyes going. Brunner had two dunks during the run, the second on a sharp bounce pass down the lane from Horner. Horner also fed Pierce for a layup, and Erek Hansen converted a three-point play before Haluska and Horner capped the burst with consecutive 3-pointers. That made it 83-54 with 2:54 remaining, and the Hawkeyes coasted from there. "We were playing too fast," Horner said. "We just had to slow down. By slowing down, we actually were able to speed up. We got some stops, got some rebounds and that led to everything." The Hawkeyes were hardly coasting early. Despite hitting four 3-pointers in the first 8 minutes, two by Horner, Iowa couldn't shake Greensboro. The Hawkeyes made sloppy passes that led to easy steals by the Spartans, who had a problem of their own: They couldn't convert. Ricky Hickman, who suffered through 4-for-14 shooting, missed a breakaway layup, Gross was left hanging helplessly on the rim after missing a dunk, and Ray Bristow couldn't get a layup down after a steal. During one stretch of less than a minute, both teams threw the ball away twice before Pierce scored on a reverse layup. After being stuck on 33 for 4 minutes, Iowa finished the half with an 8-0 run to go up 41-25. Pierce sank two free throws before hitting a long 3-pointer from the left wing, and Haluska nailed a 3 with 45 seconds left in the half.
